text: Put the protection and promotion of freedom of expression and other human rights at the center of strategies and policies on (generative) AI and digital technologies
Recognize that solutions to policy challenges like hate speech, violent extremism, propaganda, and disinformation are complex and cannot be solved by the use of automated technologies alone

Conduct thorough human rights due diligence on the potential human rights impacts of policies or regulations throughout the entire lifecycle of AI systems and digital technologies, and before enacting any such policies into law
Encourage and fund research toward AI systems fostering freedom of expression, media freedom and a diverse, healthy and resilient online information ecosystem
Create a transparent, whole-of-society approach for developing evidence-based policies that includes experts from academia, civil society, and the public
Engage internationally to ensure that freedom of expression and media freedom considerations are incorporated into national, regional and global AI strategies
Implement information and digital literacy initiatives, to inform individuals and strengthen democratic resilience
Don’t use “ethical” or “responsible” AI frameworks as a substitute for human rights-based AI governance frameworks, as ethics are neither legally binding nor enforceable
Don’t expect (generative) AI technologies to solve deeply entrenched societal problems manifesting online
Don’t disregard human rights commitments and obligations when developing laws, policies, and regulations that are applicable to the AI and tech sector
Don’t treat digital literacy as an afterthought, or exclude educating on the impact of AI and Big Tech on freedom of expression and other human rights
Don’t assume that more technology is always better, and don’t prioritize efficiency or profit over accuracy, fairness, or responsibility
Don’t enact laws or regulations based on an overly optimistic view of AI’s future capabilities, and avoid compromising the necessity of human review and judgement
Don’t adopt laws or policies from other jurisdictions without assessing their potential impact on human rights in your own country or context
